Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Analysis of Chromatin-level Mechanisms Regulating Genomic Imprinting in Mouse

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Most genes in mammals are expressed from copies inherited from both the mother and the father, but a small number of genes are only expressed from one of these two copies; these are called imprinted genes. This project aims to investigate the mechanisms that ultimately allow one copy of these imprinted genes to be expressed while the other copy remains silent, or non-functional. Understanding the regulation of these genes is important because normal patterns of mammalian growth and development are perturbed if the expression of imprinted genes is dysregulated, as when both or neither copy is expressed. These studies will be conducted at Bryn Mawr College, a women's undergraduate institution, and will provide a diverse cohort of undergraduate students with an enhanced educational environment by affording them the opportunity to use current methodologies to advance scientific exploration, ultimately preparing these undergraduate women to be the next generation of research scientists.

Imprinted genes are only expressed from one of the two parentally inherited alleles. Monoallelic expression of imprinted genes is associated with differential DNA methylation on the maternal and paternal alleles that are passed to offspring at fertilization. What remains unknown is how further refinement of chromatin structure is achieved during post-fertilization development in order to maintain imprinted expression and establish tissue-specific imprinting. Post-fertilization acquisition of DNA methylation at additional sites within imprinted loci has been proposed to serve this purpose, but DNA methylation at such secondary differentially methylated regions is highly variable. This research will test the hypotheses that the observed variability is due to increased levels of hemi-methylation and/or increased levels of 5-hydroxymethylcytosine. In addition, this work will identify cis-regulatory elements responsible for tissue-specific imprinting using chromosome conformation capture to understand how these elements work in concert with epigenetic factors to achieve monoallelic vs. biallelic expression. Overall, this research will lend insight into the mechanisms governing the establishment and maintenance of chromatin structure critical for imprinted gene expression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For most mammalian genes, the copy inherited from the mother and the copy inherited from the father both contribute to the growth and development of their offspring. However, for a small number of genes, called imprinted genes, only one of the parental copies is functional while the other copy remains silent. The cellular machinery must therefore be able to distinguish between the parental copies and regulate their expression accordingly. Failure to do so results in abnormal growth and development. This research examined how chemical and structural changes to the DNA work to achieve the appropriate expression patterns for imprinted genes.

It is known that the chemical addition of a methyl group to cytosine bases in the DNA can impact gene expression and that differences in DNA methylation deposition on the maternal vs. paternal alleles of imprinted genes regulates their expression. The DNA methylation associated with imprinted genes falls into two categories: primary differentially methylated regions (DMRs), at which methylation patterns are highly stable, and secondary DMRs, at which methylation is important for gene regulation but is significantly more variable. The variable nature of the methylation at secondary DMRs has not been well characterized, so two lines of investigation were designed to examine its molecular nature. First, this work investigated methylation patterns on the complementary strands of DNA at both primary and secondary DMRs and found that while methylation at primary DMRs is asymmetrical at less than 10% of the sites analyzed, secondary DMRs display methylation asymmetry at 30-50% of the analyzed sites. This result held true for all secondary DMRs analyzed, regardless of whether the methylation was on the paternal or maternal allele, illustrating that methylation variability is a general feature of secondary DMRs. This work then investigated a possible cause of methylation asymmetry by assessing the amount of a modified form of methylated cytosine, 5-hydroxymethylcytosine (5hmC), which prevents DNA methylation patterns from being faithfully propagated. There was a direct correlation between 5hmC enrichment and high levels of methylation asymmetry at the secondary DMRs that are methylated on the paternal allele, but not at the secondary DMRs that are methylated on the maternal allele. While this result suggests that there may be differences in the way that paternally vs. maternally methylated sequences are regulated, the methodology employed in this study limited the breadth of the analysis. Current research is focused on interrogating these sequences more comprehensively in order to better quantify the levels of 5hmC at each genomic location and determine if there are statistically significant differences in 5hmC enrichment at paternally vs maternally methylated DMRs as well as vs. non-imprinted genes. Furthermore, although in theory the presence of 5hmC should lead to methylation loss over time, this is not what we observed; rather, although the methylation patterns are variable at secondary DMRs, overall methylation levels are consistent across development. Therefore, we propose that methylation is both lost and regained at secondary DMRs throughout the organisms lifetime. Future research will test this hypothesis using a mouse strain with a mutation that compromises DNA methylation maintenance.

A third line of investigation was an analysis of the three-dimensional chromosome structure around the imprinted Rasgrf1 gene. Rasgrf1 is only expressed from the paternal allele in some tissues, such as brain, but is expressed from both the maternal and paternal alleles in other tissues, such as lung. We hypothesized that differences in chromatin structure cause this gene to be regulated differently in these two tissue types. Our findings indicate that the chromatin structure around Rasgrf1 is highly similar in different tissue types, but that there may be some tissue-specific differences that could account for different expression patterns. Additional work will be necessary to determine if the differences we detected have biological significance.

This research was conducted by twelve undergraduate women, each of whom worked on an independent project related to the overall goals, creating a pipeline of sophisticated students who are prepared for graduate and medical school as well as to serve as research assistants in laboratories engaged in molecular genetic research. Some of the funds from this project were specifically dedicated to fostering research opportunities and mentor/mentee relationships for students in Bryn Mawr College?s STEM Posse. The Posse Foundation (http://www.possefoundation.org) provides scholarships to a diverse cohort of students from urban public high schools who have demonstrated both academic and leadership potential, but may be overlooked by traditional college admissions processes, and Bryn Mawr College hosted the first all-women?s STEM Posse in 2013-2014. Three Posse scholars were supported by this research and two are authors on a recently accepted paper. One Posse scholar is currently in graduate school, one is a senior planning to apply to medical school and one is is a junior planning to apply to graduate school.
